Expectation1: Provide initial medical care to patients
Situation1: The ambulance driver is conducting a routine check of the first-aid kit to ensure all supplies are present and not expired.
Situation2: They notice a local festival happening nearby and casually stop to observe some of the decorations and rituals.
Story:
I was checking the first-aid kit in the back of my ambulance, making sure every bandage and vial was in place, when the sound of drums and laughter drifted through the open door. Just across the street, the neighborhood was alive with color—marigold garlands, incense smoke, and the rhythmic chanting of a Hindu festival. My heart tugged toward the celebration; today was a special day, one my family and community had been preparing for all week. I could almost feel the sandalwood paste on my forehead, the warmth of the diya in my hands.

But as I lingered, my mind kept circling back to the ambulance. I was expected to be ready, to provide care at a moment’s notice. If a call came in, I’d have to drop everything and go, no matter how much I wanted to join the prayers and rituals. The weight of my uniform pressed against my skin, a reminder of my duty. Yet, the pull of my faith was just as strong, whispering that I belonged among the devotees, not just as a bystander but as a participant. I stood there, torn, the sounds of celebration and the sterile scent of antiseptic mingling in the air, unsure which role I could honor without betraying the other.
